topics.title: Content market fit as product market fit
topics.summary: Camille explains that content needs its own “market fit”: clearly define the audience, their anxieties, and what they need to succeed, then build content that directly addresses those needs.

topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces the show and Camille’s background (Notion, First Round Review, Kiva, Tesla), and frames the episode around community-led growth and content marketing.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor reads for Eppo (A/B testing), Flatfile (CSV/data onboarding), and later Vanta (SOC 2 compliance).

topics.title: Camille’s career path: journalism to Notion
topics.summary: Camille walks through her path from the Wall Street Journal to Tesla, First Round Capital (launching First Round Review), and joining Notion as the first marketing hire.

topics.title: Lessons from Tesla and working with Elon
topics.summary: Camille shares what it was like supporting Elon Musk in press interactions, emphasizing being extremely prepared and communicating an emotionally compelling mission.

topics.title: Early Notion: employee 11 and startup life
topics.summary: Camille describes joining Notion as employee #11, the early office vibe, and how the team’s shared hardships (no HVAC/lighting) became cherished memories.

topics.title: Notion outage: crisis response and community support
topics.summary: Camille recounts the January 2021 outage, the scramble to communicate status updates, and how user empathy on social channels reinforced Notion’s importance and the value of community.

topics.title: Defining community-led growth and measuring discovery
topics.summary: Camille defines community-led growth as community-driven ubiquity that de-risks adoption and enables moving upmarket; she highlights net-new website visitors as a key “discovery” metric and notes influencer attribution as more measurable.

topics.title: What worked at Notion: ambassadors, events, influencers
topics.summary: Camille details the biggest community levers: ambassador programs, in-person events (global scale), and influencer marketing; she explains aligning incentives by helping community members achieve their own goals.

topics.title: ROI, founder belief, and when community fits
topics.summary: They discuss when to invest in community, why early-stage over-measurement can be harmful, and why community works best for freemium/PLG products with a shareable “atomic unit” (e.g., templates).

topics.title: Notion creator economy: templates and consultants
topics.summary: Camille explains how Notion users built real businesses selling templates and consulting, and how nurturing these paths strengthened adoption—especially inside companies relying on expert implementers.

topics.title: Ambassadors vs champions: program structures
topics.summary: Camille distinguishes ambassadors (passionate builders/sharers) from champions (power users inside customer companies), describing Slack-based communities that create peer support, feedback loops, and customer success leverage.

topics.title: How to build community: listen, don’t prescribe
topics.summary: Camille emphasizes avoiding one-size-fits-all community design, doing deep 1:1 listening, and choosing between ubiquity vs near-term revenue depending on company goals and motion.

topics.title: Community examples and a two-by-two framework
topics.summary: Camille cites Figma and Stripe (Atlas) as community-led exemplars and introduces a 2x2 (PMF vs pre-PMF; enterprise vs consumer) to choose the right community form, including CABs, champions, and consultants.

topics.title: Designing an ambassador program and keeping it healthy
topics.summary: Camille explains how Notion started with ~20 highly vocal users, rewarded them with early feature access, AMAs, event support, and promotion; she advises slow, intentional growth and shares “commandments” like not chasing metrics too early.
